name: Sacramento Food Bank & Family Services
description: Provides food and family services to individuals and families in need.
hours: Mon-Fri 8am-4pm (check website for specific program hours)
restrictions: Proof of residency and income may be required for some services.
next_steps: Visit the website or call for information on services and how to apply.

name: Loaves & Fishes
description: Provides survival services, such as meals, showers, and laundry facilities, for homeless men, women, and children.
hours: Varies by service (see website for details)
next_steps: Visit the campus during operating hours for assistance.

name: Sacramento SPCA
description: Provides shelter, veterinary care, and adoption services for animals in the Sacramento region.
hours: Varies by service (see website for details)
restrictions: Adoption fees apply. Spay/neuter services may have income restrictions.
next_steps: Visit the shelter during open hours or browse available animals online for adoption. Call for veterinary appointments.

name: Ronald McDonald House Charities Northern California
description: Provides a 'home away from home' for families of children receiving medical care at nearby hospitals.
hours: Open 24 hours for families staying at the house (see website for visitation hours)
restrictions: Families must have a child receiving medical care at a partner hospital.
next_steps: Contact the house directly or speak with hospital social workers to arrange a stay.

name: Children's Receiving Home of Sacramento
description: Provides emergency shelter and support services for children who have experienced abuse or neglect.
hours: Open 24 hours for children in need
restrictions: Services are for children under the auspices of the Department of Health and Human Services and the Superior Court.
next_steps: Contact Child Protective Services or law enforcement if you are concerned about a child's safety. Contact the Receiving Home directly for information on their services.

name: Center for Fathers and Families
description: Strengthens families and builds communities by offering programs and services focused on father involvement.
next_steps: Visit the website or call for information on programs and enrollment.

name: Sacramento Steps Forward
description: Works to end homelessness in Sacramento County by providing coordinated services and advocacy.
restrictions: Clients must meet program eligibility requirements.
next_steps: If you are experiencing homelessness, call 2-1-1 or visit a Coordinated Access System (CAS) access point for assistance.

name: Alta California Regional Center
description: Provides services and support for individuals with developmental disabilities and their families.
restrictions: Must meet California's eligibility criteria for developmental disabilities services.
next_steps: Visit the website or call to begin the intake and assessment process.

name: City Year Sacramento
description: Places young adults in public schools to serve as tutors and mentors.
restrictions: Students must be enrolled in partner schools.
next_steps: Contact your child's school to inquire about City Year's presence and services.

name: Team Giving, Inc.
address: 2030 W El Camino Ave #210, Sacramento, CA 95833
description: Connects volunteers with local nonprofits to strengthen the Sacramento community.
next_steps: Visit the website to browse volunteer opportunities and register as a volunteer.

name: Sacramento LGBT Community Center
description: Provides a safe space, resources, and support to the LGBTQ+ community in Sacramento.
hours: Mon-Fri 10am-5pm (check website for specific program hours and events)
restrictions: None mentioned for most services. Emergency shelter and some specific programs may have eligibility requirements.
next_steps: Visit the website or call for information on resources and programs

name: Environmental Council of Sacramento (ECOS)
description: A coalition that works to achieve regional sustainability, livable communities, environmental justice, and a healthy environment and economy in the Sacramento region.
next_steps: Visit the website to learn about current initiatives, volunteer opportunities, and how to get involved.

name: Legal Services of Northern California
description: Provides free civil legal services to low-income, disabled, and senior clients in Northern California.
restrictions: Clients must meet income and residency requirements.

name: NAMI Sacramento (National Alliance on Mental Illness)
description: Provides support, education, and advocacy for individuals and families affected by mental illness.

name: Agency on Aging Area 4
description: Provides a variety of services to seniors and their families, including information and referral, nutrition assistance (CalFresh), transportation, and elder abuse prevention.
restrictions: Services may be limited to individuals 60 years or older or those with specific needs. Eligibility requirements may apply for some programs.
next_steps: Visit the website or call for information on available services and eligibility requirements.

name: Wildlife Care Association of Sacramento
description: Rescues, rehabilitates, and releases local wildlife in the Sacramento region.
next_steps: If you find injured or orphaned wildlife, contact the hotline immediately. Visit the website to learn how to help or become a volunteer.

name: Northern California Arts, Inc
description: Promotes the appreciation of and participation in the visual arts and spearheads art education in the Sacramento community.
hours: Varies by event and program (check website)
restrictions: Some classes or events may have fees or membership requirements.

name: 350 Sacramento
description: A grassroots climate justice organization focused on collective action to create a safe global climate and accelerate the transition to a sustainable future.
hours: Varies by event and meeting schedule (check website)

name: Capital Pro Bono
description: Provides free legal assistance to low-income people in the Sacramento region.

name: California LGBTQ Foundation
description: Supports the LGBTQ community through events and donations to charities, fosters civic engagement, and develops community leaders.

name: Maryland Food Bank
description: The Maryland Food Bank is a non-profit organization that provides food to local pantries throughout Maryland.

name: Moveable Feast
description: Moveable Feast is a non-profit organization in Baltimore City fostering a community that cares for men, women and children living with HIV/AIDS, cancer, and other life-threatening illnesses by preparing and delivering nutritious meals and groceries and providing nutritional counseling and other services.

name: Maryland SPCA
description: The Maryland SPCA is an independent, non-profit organization providing innovative programs in education, veterinary services and humane care to improve the lives of thousands of pets and people in communities throughout the state of Maryland.

name: St. Francis Neighborhood Center
description: St. Francis Neighborhood Center is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit dedicated to dismantling inequity by cultivating community connections through tailored education and social interventions for West Baltimore.

name: Center for Urban Families
description: The Center for Urban Families is a community center that provides employment programs and support for men with child support payments and returning citizens.

name: United Way of Central Maryland
description: The United Way of Central Maryland works to improve lives by focusing on education, financial stability, and health in Central Maryland.

name: Ronald McDonald House Charities Maryland
description: Ronald McDonald House Charities Maryland provides a 'home away from home' for families with seriously ill children receiving treatment at nearby hospitals.

name: Associated Black Charities Inc
address: 2 Hamill Road, 302 East Quadrangle, Baltimore, MD 21210, USA, East Quadrangle Building
description: Associated Black Charities is a racial equity organization that works as an educator, advocate, supporter, and convener to address and eliminate the barriers created by structural racism and to advance long-term solutions that create new opportunities for Black people to thrive.

name: Associated Catholic Charities
description: Catholic Charities of Baltimore has 80 programs across 200 locations in Maryland. They serve people in need in the areas of mental health, senior services, immigrants, and poverty relief.

name: Julie Community Center
address: 100 S Washington St, Baltimore, MD 21231, US
description: The Julie Community Center works with residents of east/southeast Baltimore, particularly those on low or fixed incomes, to help them access needed resources and support, and develop instruments that combat poverty and urban decline, and foster individual and neighborhood pride, participation, and self-determination.

name: FLO - Friendly Loving Opportunities
description: Friendly Loving Opportunities (FLO) is a nonprofit organization that helps families in need, veterans and the homeless in the greater Baltimore area by providing food, clothing, furniture, and supplies, and runs a vintage furniture store to help generate revenue to sustain their mission.
next_steps: Visit website or call for details on receiving services.

name: The Community Group Inc
address: 1400 Federal St Suite #109, Baltimore, MD 21213, US

next_steps: Visit website or call to learn more about their programs.

name: NAMI Metropolitan Baltimore
address: 2601 N Howard St Suite 130, Baltimore, MD 21218, US

name: Habitat for Humanity of the Chesapeake
description: Habitat Chesapeake builds and renovates homes to provide affordable housing for families in Baltimore City, Baltimore, Anne Arundel, and Howard counties, and operates ReStores selling donated items to fund their mission.

name: HealthCare Access Maryland
address: 1 N Charles St Suite 900, Baltimore, MD 21201, US

name: Druid Heights Community Development Corporation

name: J.O.Y. Baltimore

name: Black Mental Health Alliance for Education and Consultation, Inc.

name: Baltimore Office of Promotion & The Arts

name: Capital Area Food Bank
address: 4900 Puerto Rico Ave NE, Washington, DC 20017, US
description: The Capital Area Food Bank is the largest organization in the Washington metro area working to solve hunger and its companion problems: chronic undernutrition, heart disease, and obesity. By partnering with 444 community organizations in DC, MD, and VA, as well as delivering food directly into hard to reach areas, the CAFB provides meals to 12% of the Washington metro area population.

name: United Way of the National Capital Area
address: 1015 15th St NW Suite 1200, Washington, DC 20005, US
description: United Way of the National Capital Area fights for the health, education and financial stability of every person in the community. They improve the lives of under-served individuals by focusing the most effective community resources on creating measurable and lasting impact.

name: Urban Alliance
address: 2030 Q St NW, Washington, DC 20009, US

name: Coalition For the Homeless
address: 1131 Spring Rd NW, Washington, DC 20010, US

name: Bread For The City - Food Distribution Center

They provide food, clothing, medical care, and legal and social services to reduce the burden of poverty. They also seek justice through community organizing and public advocacy.

name: Miriam's Kitchen

name: DC Central Kitchen
